citations.narrative:
The enclosure for the spider monkey was 71 inches tall. Spider monkeys are a brachiating species and require enough
space to exhibit species typical behavior in order to ensure their physical and behavioral wellbeing.
The spider monkey should be provided with 25.1 square feet of floor space that is 84 inches in height in order to meet the
minimum required space per the regulations.
Correction Date: February 20th, 2023

The enclosure housing the two wallabies had a rubber mat that covered about 3 quarters of the floor and one quarter of
the floor was dirt. There was a bucket of water that had spilled on the dirt portion of the floor and run over partly onto the
rubber mat. The dirt portion of the floor was muddy and the mat was damp. There was no bedding provided to protect the
animals from becoming wet or muddy.
Facilities must be constructed and maintained in a way to rapidly and sanitarily eliminate excess water and provide clean
dry space for animals.
Corrected by January 26th, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
There was an incomplete written environmental enrichment plan for the birds. The plan provided was a copy of the USDA
regulations and did not address the individual plans needed for the species of birds present at the facility.
Insufficient enrichment for birds can cause psychological distress to birds and can lead to aggression or self-injurious
behavior. A complete written enrichment plan must be established, approved by the attending veterinarian and be made
available to USDA inspectors.

There were fours doves that had scabbed over wounds covering one quarter to half of their heads. The licensee reported
that the injuries had taken place when the doves were housed with three pigeons. When the injuries had been noticed the
doves were moved into an enclosure with only doves and the wounds have begun to heal.
Birds must be housed with compatible species that do not cause injury, restrict access to food, water, and shelter, or are
in any other way hazardous to their health or wellbeing.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
REBECCA NANNEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.80(b)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The enclosure for the spider monkey was 71 inches tall. Spider monkeys are a brachiating species and require enough 
space to exhibit species typical behavior in order to ensure their physical and behavioral wellbeing.  
The spider monkey should be provided with 25.1 square feet of floor space that is 84 inches in height in order to meet the 
minimum required space per the regulations. 
Correction Date: February 20th, 2023 
3.126(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
The enclosure housing the two wallabies had a rubber mat that covered about 3 quarters of the floor and one quarter of 
the floor was dirt. There was a bucket of water that had spilled on the dirt portion of the floor and run over partly onto the 
rubber mat. The dirt portion of the floor was muddy and the mat was damp. There was no bedding provided to protect the 
animals from becoming wet or muddy.  
Facilities must be constructed and maintained in a way to rapidly and sanitarily eliminate excess water and provide clean 
dry space for animals.  
Corrected by January 26th, 2024 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
There was an incomplete written environmental enrichment plan for the birds. The plan provided was a copy of the USDA 
regulations and did not address the individual plans needed for the species of birds present at the facility.  
Insufficient enrichment for birds can cause psychological distress to birds and can lead to aggression or self-injurious 
behavior. A complete written enrichment plan must be established, approved by the attending veterinarian and be made 
available to USDA inspectors. 
3.160(b)  Repeat
   
Compatibility and separation

There were fours doves that had scabbed over wounds covering one quarter to half of their heads. The licensee reported 
that the injuries had taken place when the doves were housed with three pigeons. When the injuries had been noticed the 
doves were moved into an enclosure with only doves and the wounds have begun to heal.  
Birds must be housed with compatible species that do not cause injury, restrict access to food, water, and shelter, or are 
in any other way hazardous to their health or wellbeing. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
REBECCA NANNEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
